ElementDef.EDComments: The <Origin\> element is used in predominantly consolidated Bills. These are Bills which are made up of a number of other Bills (i.e. they are consolidated). The original source is referenced in the <Origin\> element. The origins are then used to construct the tables of origins and destinations using the AutoTables plugins.

ElementDef.EDComments: This element was called <InternalReference\> in Release 33 and below. It was changed to <Xref\> as it was becoming more widely used to create cross references between files.
This element is used to create cross references to <Chapter\> elements within the Bill book. Upon concatenation they are converted into regular <Xref\> elements.

The <DummyXref\> element is used within House amendments to indicate where a cross reference would be required when it is introduced into the Bill text. It is not intended for use within Bill text only.
This element is used to create cross references to <Part\> elements within the Bill book. Upon concatenation they are converted into regular <Xref\> elements.

Subsection (9A) applies (subject to subsection (9B)) where the local
authority are a local authority in England and
are considering adoption for C, or
are satisfied that C ought to be placed for adoption but are
not authorised under section 19 of the Adoption and
Children Act 2002 (placement with parental consent) or by
virtue of section 21 of that Act (placement orders) to place C
for adoption.

subsections (7) to (9) do not apply to the local authority,
the local authority must consider placing C with an
individual within subsection (6)(a), and
where the local authority decide that a placement with such
an individual is not the most appropriate placement for C,
the local authority must consider placing C with a local
authority foster parent who has been approved as a
prospective adopter.

applied for a placement order under section 21 of the Adoption and
Children Act 2002 in respect of C and the application has been
refused.\xd3 \xd3

After Clause
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Right to mediation
This section applies where
a decision against which an appeal may be brought under section
51 is made in respect of a child or young person, or
an EHC plan for a child or young person is made, amended or
replaced.
Before the end of the prescribed period after the decision is made, or the
plan is made, amended or replaced, the local authority must notify the
child\xd5 s parent or the young person of
the right to mediation under section (
Mediation: health care issues
) or
Mediation: educational and social care issues etc
), and
the requirement to obtain a certificate under section
52 before
making certain appeals.
If the parent or young person wishes to pursue mediation under section
Mediation: health care issues
) or (
Mediation: educational and social care issues
etc
), he or she must inform the local authority of
that fact, and
the issues in respect of which he or she wishes to pursue mediation
(\xd2 the mediation issues\xd3 ).
If the mediation issues are, or include, the fact that no health care provision,
or no health care provision of a particular kind, is specified in the plan, the
parent or young person must also inform the local authority of the health
care provision which he or she wishes to be specified in the plan.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Mediation: health care issues
This section applies where
the parent or young person informs the local authority under
section (
Right to mediation
) that he or she wishes to pursue
mediation, and
the mediation issues include health care provision specified in the
plan or the fact that no health care provision, or no health care
provision of a particular kind, is specified in the plan.
The local authority must notify each relevant commissioning body of
the mediation issues, and
anything of which it has been informed by the parent or young
person under section (
Right to mediation
If the mediation issues are limited to the health care provision specified in
the plan or the fact that no health care provision, or no health care provision
of a particular kind, is specified in the plan, the responsible commissioning
body (or, where there is more than one, the responsible commissioning
bodies acting jointly) must
arrange for mediation between it (or them) and the parent or young
person,
ensure that the mediation is conducted by an independent person,
and
participate in the mediation.
If the mediation issues include anything else
the local authority must
arrange for mediation between it, each responsible
commissioning body and the parent or young person,
ensure that the mediation is conducted by an independent
person, and
participate in the mediation, and
each responsible commissioning body must also participate in the
mediation.
For the purposes of this section, a person is not independent if he or she is
employed by any of the following
a local authority in England;
a clinical commissioning group;
the National Health Service Commissioning Board.
In this section \xd2 responsible commissioning body\xd3
if the mediation issues in question are or include the health care
provision specified in an EHC plan, means a body that is under a
duty to arrange health care provision of that kind in respect of the
child or young person;
if the mediation issues in question are or include the fact that no
health care provision, or no health care provision of a particular
kind, is specified in an EHC plan, means a body that would be
under a duty to arrange health care provision of the kind in
question if it were specified in the plan.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Mediation: educational and social care issues etc
This section applies where
the parent or young person informs the local authority under
section (
Right to mediation
) that he or she wishes to pursue
mediation, and
the mediation issues do not include health care provision specified
in the plan or the fact that no health care provision, or no health care
provision of a particular kind, is specified in the plan.
The local authority must
arrange for mediation between it and the parent or young person,
ensure that the mediation is conducted by an independent person,
and
participate in the mediation.
For the purposes of this section, a person is not independent if he or she is
employed by a local authority in England.\xd3

Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Assessment of post-detention education, health and care needs of detained
persons
This section applies in relation to a detained person for whom
the home authority is a local authority in England, and
no EHC plan is being kept by a local authority.
A request to the home authority to secure a detained person\xd5 s EHC needs
assessment for the detained person may be made by
the appropriate person, or
the person in charge of the relevant youth accommodation where
the detained person is detained.
Where this subsection applies, the home authority must determine
whether it may be necessary for special educational provision to be made
for the detained person in accordance with an EHC plan on release from
detention.

Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Duty to keep EHC plans for detained persons
This section applies in relation to a detained person
for whom a local authority in England was maintaining an EHC
plan immediately before the beginning of his or her detention, or
for whom the home authority has secured the preparation of an
EHC plan under section (
Securing EHC plans for certain detained
persons
The home authority must keep the EHC plan while the person is detained
in relevant youth accommodation.
Regulations may make provision about the keeping of EHC plans under
subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.ecitsuj htuoY-1188680: SubSection: (2) The home authority must keep the EHC plan while the person is detained in relevant youth accommodation.

The home authority must arrange appropriate special educational
provision for the detained person while he or she is detained in relevant
youth accommodation.
If the EHC plan specifies health care provision, the detained person\xd5 s
health services commissioner must arrange appropriate health care
provision for the detained person while he or she is detained in relevant
youth accommodation.
For the purposes of subsection

corresponding as closely as possible to that special educational
provision, or
if it appears to the home authority that the special educational
provision specified in the plan is no longer appropriate for the
person, such special educational provision as reasonably appears to

Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Review of resolution of disagreements
The Secretary of State and the Lord Chancellor must carry out a review of
how effectively disagreements about the exercise of functions under this
Part are being resolved.
The Secretary of State and the Lord Chancellor must prepare a report on the
outcome of the review.
The Secretary of State and the Lord Chancellor must lay the report before
Parliament before the end of the period of three years beginning with the
earliest date on which any provision of this Part comes into force.\xd3

Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Discharge of authority\xd5 s duty to secure free early years provision
Part 1 of the Childcare Act 2006 (general functions of local authorities in
England in relation to childcare) is amended as follows.
After section 7 (duty to secure early years provision free of charge in
accordance with regulations) insert
Discharge of duty under section 7
Regulations may require an English local authority to discharge its
duty to a young child under section 7 by making arrangements
which secure that an early years provider chosen by a parent of the
child provides the early years provision to which the child is
entitled in cases where
the early years provider is willing to provide it, and
the early years provider is also willing to accept
any terms as to the payments which would be made
to him or her in respect of the provision, and
any requirements which would be imposed in
respect of it.
Arrangements made by an authority to satisfy any requirement
imposed under subsection (1) may be made with an early years
provider or with an early years childminder agency or any other
person who is able to arrange for an early years provider to provide
early years provision.
The regulations may provide that such a requirement
applies only if the early years provider is of a prescribed
description;
applies only if the early years provision provided by the
early years provider is of a prescribed description;
does not apply in prescribed circumstances.
The regulations may provide that arrangements made by an
authority for the purpose of complying with such a requirement
must include provision allowing the local authority to terminate the
arrangements in prescribed circumstances.
In this section

Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Extension of licensing of child performances to children under 14
Section 38 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1963 (licences for
performances by children under 14 not to be granted except for certain
dramatic or musical performances) is repealed.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Purchase of tobacco etc. on behalf of persons under 18
A person aged 18 or over who buys or attempts to buy tobacco or cigarette
papers on behalf of an individual aged under 18 commits an offence.
Where a person is charged with an offence under this section it is a
defence
that the person had no reason to suspect that the individual
concerned was aged under 18, or
in a case where the person has bought or attempted to buy cigarette
papers, that the person had no reason to suspect that the individual
concerned intended to use the papers for smoking.
A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable on summary
conviction to a fine not exceeding level 4 on the standard scale.
A local weights and measures authority in England and Wales must
enforce the provisions of this section in its area.
Section 9 of, and Schedule 1 to, the Health Act 2006 (issue of fixed penalty
notices in relation to certain smoking related offences) apply in relation to
an offence under this section as they apply in relation to an offence under
section 6(5) or 7(2) of that Act but with the following modifications
references to an enforcement authority are to be read as references
to a local weights and measures authority;
references to an authorised officer of an enforcement authority are
to be read as references to any person authorised by a local weights
and measures authority (whether or not an officer of the authority)
in writing, either generally or specially, to act in matters arising
under this section.
Section 11 of, and Schedule 2 to, the Health Act 2006 (offence of obstruction
of enforcement officers and powers of entry etc) apply for the purposes of
this section as they apply for the purposes of Chapter 1 of Part 1 of that Act
but with the following modifications
references to an enforcement authority are to be read as references
to a local weights and measures authority;
references to an authorised officer of an enforcement authority are
to be read as references to any person (whether or not an officer of
the authority) authorised by a local weights and measures authority
in writing, either generally or specially, to act in matters arising
under this section;
references to Chapter 1 of Part 1 of the Act of 2006 are to be read as
references to this section;
section 11(5) is to be ignored;
paragraph 10 of Schedule 2 is to be ignored.
\xd2 Tobacco\xd3 has the same meaning in this section as in section 7 of the
Children and Young Persons Act 1933 (offence of selling tobacco to
children).\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Prohibition of sale of nicotine products to persons under 18
The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision prohibiting the
sale of nicotine products to persons aged under 18.
A person who breaches a prohibition in regulations under subsection
commits an offence.
Subsection
does not apply if
at the time of the sale, the person to whom the nicotine product is
sold is employed by a manufacturer of nicotine products to which
regulations under subsection
apply or by a dealer in such
products (whether wholesale or retail), and
the purchase of the product is for the purposes of the
manufacturer\xd5 s or dealer\xd5 s business.
Where a person is charged with an offence under this section it is a defence
that the person took all reasonable precautions and exercised all due
diligence to avoid committing the offence.
A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable on summary
conviction to a fine not exceeding level 4 on the standard scale.
The Secretary of State may by regulations
amend section (
Purchase of tobacco etc. on behalf of persons under 18
(purchase of tobacco etc on behalf of persons under 18) so as to
apply it (with or without modifications) in relation to nicotine
products, or
provide for that section to apply (with or without modifications) in
relation to nicotine products.
Regulations under this section may make provision in relation to
all nicotine products,
nicotine products of a specified kind, or
nicotine products subject to specified exceptions.
The Secretary of State must obtain the consent of the Welsh Ministers
before making regulations under this section which would (if contained in
an Act of the National Assembly for Wales) be within the legislative
competence of that Assembly.
For the purposes of this section \xd2 nicotine product\xd3 means
a device which is intended to enable nicotine to be consumed by an
individual or otherwise to be delivered into the human body,
an item which is intended to form part of a device within paragraph
(a), or
a substance or item which consists of or contains nicotine and
which is intended for human consumption or otherwise to be
delivered into the human body.
It does not matter for the purposes of subsection
(a) whether the device
is also intended to enable any other substance to be consumed by an
individual or otherwise to be delivered into the human body.
The following are not nicotine products for the purposes of this section
tobacco;
cigarette papers;
any device which is intended to be used for the consumption of lit
tobacco.
In this section
\xd2 specified\xd3 means specified in regulations under this section;
\xd2 tobacco\xd3 has the same meaning as in section 7 of the Children and
Young Persons Act 1933 (offence of selling tobacco to children).\xd3

Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Regulation of retail packaging etc of tobacco products
The Secretary of State may make regulations under subsection
or
if
the Secretary of State considers that the regulations may contribute at any
time to reducing the risk of harm to, or promoting, the health or welfare of
people under the age of 18.
Subsection
does not prevent the Secretary of State, in making
regulations under subsection
or
, from considering whether the
regulations may contribute at any time to reducing the risk of harm to, or
promoting, the health or welfare of people aged 18 or over.
The Secretary of State may treat regulations under subsection
or
as
capable of contributing to reducing the risk of harm to, or promoting, the
health or welfare of people under the age of 18 if the Secretary of State
considers that
at least some of the provisions of the regulations are capable of
having that effect, or
the regulations are capable of having that effect when taken
together with other regulations that were previously made under
subsection
or
and are in force.
Regulations under subsection
or
are to be treated for the purposes of
subsection
or
as capable of contributing to reducing the risk of harm
to, or promoting, people\xd5 s health or welfare if (for example) they may
contribute to any of the following
discouraging people from starting to use tobacco products;
encouraging people to give up using tobacco products;
helping people who have given up, or are trying to give up, using
tobacco products not to start using them again;
reducing the appeal or attractiveness of tobacco products;
reducing the potential for elements of the packaging of tobacco
products other than health warnings to detract from the
effectiveness of those warnings;
reducing opportunities for the packaging of tobacco products to
mislead consumers about the effects of using them;
reducing opportunities for the packaging of tobacco products to
create false perceptions about the nature of such products;
having an effect on attitudes, beliefs, intentions and behaviours
relating to the reduction in use of tobacco products.
Regulations under subsection
or
are to be treated for the purposes of
subsection
as capable of contributing to reducing the risk of harm to, or
promoting, the health or welfare of people under the age of 18 if
they may contribute to reducing activities by such people which
risk harming their health or welfare after they reach the age of 18, or
they may benefit such people by reducing the use of tobacco
products among people aged 18 or over.
The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision about the retail
packaging of tobacco products.
Regulations under subsection
may in particular impose prohibitions,
requirements or limitations relating to
the markings on the retail packaging of tobacco products (including
the use of branding, trademarks or logos);
the appearance of such packaging;
the materials used for such packaging;
the texture of such packaging;
the size of such packaging;
the shape of such packaging;
the means by which such packaging is opened;
any other features of the retail packaging of tobacco products which
could be used to distinguish between different brands of tobacco
product;
the number of individual tobacco products contained in an
individual packet;
the quantity of a tobacco product contained in an individual packet.
The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision imposing
prohibitions, requirements or limitations relating to
the markings on tobacco products (including the use of branding,
trademarks or logos);
the appearance of such products;
the size of such products;
the shape of such products;
the flavour of such products;
any other features of tobacco products which could be used to
distinguish between different brands of tobacco product.
The Secretary of State may by regulations
create offences which may be committed by persons who produce
or supply tobacco products the retail packaging of which breaches
prohibitions, requirements or limitations imposed by regulations
under subsection
create offences which may be committed by persons who produce

requirements or limitations imposed by regulations under
subsection
provide for exceptions and defences to such offences;
make provision about the liability of others to be convicted of such
offences if committed by a body corporate or a Scottish partnership.
The Secretary of State may by regulations
provide that regulations under subsection
or
are to be treated
for the purposes specified in regulations under this subsection as
safety regulations within the meaning of the Consumer Protection
make provision for the appropriate minister to direct, in relation to

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision amending,

or
The Secretary of State must

or

For the purposes of this section a person produces a tobacco product if, in
the course of a business and with a view to the product being supplied for
consumption in the United Kingdom or through the travel retail sector, the
person
manufactures the product,
puts a name, trademark or other distinguishing mark on it by which
the person is held out to be its manufacturer or originator, or
imports it into the United Kingdom.
For the purposes of this section a person supplies a tobacco product if in the
course of a business the person
supplies the product,
offers or agrees to supply it, or
exposes or possesses it for supply.
In this section
\xd2 appropriate minister\xd3
in relation to England, means the Secretary of State,
in relation to Wales, means the Welsh Ministers,
in relation to Northern Ireland, means the Department of
Health, Social Services and Public Safety, and
in relation to Scotland, means the Scottish Ministers;
\xd2 enactment\xd3 includes
an Act of the Scottish Parliament,
a Measure or Act of the National Assembly for Wales, or
Northern Ireland legislation;
\xd2 external packaging\xd3 , \xd2 internal packaging\xd3 and \xd2 wrapper\xd3 have the
meanings given by regulations under subsection
\xd2 packaging\xd3 , in relation to a tobacco product, means
the external packaging of that product,
any internal packaging of that product,
any wrapper of that product, or
any other material attached to or included with that product
or anything within paragraphs (a) to (c);
\xd2 retail packaging\xd3 , in relation to a tobacco product, means the
packaging in which it is, or is intended to be, presented for retail
sale;
\xd2 retail sale\xd3 means sale otherwise than to a person who is acting in the
course of a business which is part of the tobacco trade;
\xd2 tobacco product\xd3 means a product consisting wholly or partly of
tobacco and intended to be smoked, sniffed, sucked or chewed;
\xd2 travel retail sector\xd3 means retail outlets in the United Kingdom at
which tobacco products may be purchased only by people
travelling on journeys to destinations outside the United
Kingdom.\xd3

Regulations under this section may in particular provide for

under this section\xd3 .
In section 9 (fixed penalties), after subsection (1) insert
The appropriate national authority may by regulations provide
that, in the circumstances specified in the regulations, an authorised
officer of an enforcement authority (see section 10) who has reason
to believe that a person has committed an offence under section 8(4)
in relation to a vehicle in relation to which the authorised officer has
functions may give the person a penalty notice in respect of the
offence.\xd3
In section 10(1) (power to designate bodies or descriptions of body as
enforcement authorities)
after \xd2 designating the\xd3 insert \xd2 persons or\xd3 , and
after \xd2 descriptions of\xd3 insert \xd2 person or\xd3 .
In section 79 (orders and regulations)
in subsection (4) (powers to which affirmative procedure applies),
in paragraph (a) (powers in Part 1), for \xd2 or 8(7)\xd3 substitute \xd2 , 8(7) or

8\xd3 substitute \xd2 , 8 or 17\xd3 , and

No statutory instrument containing regulations under
section 9(1A) or paragraph 17 of Schedule 1 may be made by
the Welsh Ministers unless a draft of the instrument has
been laid before, and approved by a resolution of, the
National Assembly for Wales.\xd3
In Schedule 1 (fixed penalties), after paragraph 16 insert
\xd2 Power to amend or modify Schedule
The appropriate national authority may by regulations

Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Young carers
In Part 3 of the Children Act 1989, after section 17 insert
Young carers\xd5 needs assessments: England
A local authority in England must assess whether a young carer
within their area has needs for support and, if so, what those needs
are, if
it appears to the authority that the young carer may have
needs for support, or
the authority receive a request from the young carer or a
parent of the young carer to assess the young carer\xd5 s needs
for support.
An assessment under subsection (1) is referred to in this Part as a
\xd2 young carer\xd5 s needs assessment\xd3 .
In this Part \xd2 young carer\xd3 means a person under 18 who provides
or intends to provide care for another person (but this is qualified
by section 17ZB(3)).
Subsection (1) does not apply in relation to a young carer if the local
authority have previously carried out a care-related assessment of
the young carer in relation to the same person cared for.
But subsection (1) does apply (and so a young carer\xd5 s needs
assessment must be carried out) if it appears to the authority that
the needs or circumstances of the young carer or the person cared
for have changed since the last care-related assessment.
\xd2 Care-related assessment\xd3 means
a young carer\xd5 s needs assessment;
an assessment under any of the following
section 1 of the Carers (Recognition and Services)
section 1 of the Carers and Disabled Children Act
section 4(3) of the Community Care (Delayed
Discharges) Act 2003.
A young carer\xd5 s needs assessment must include an assessment of
whether it is appropriate for the young carer to provide, or continue
to provide, care for the person in question, in the light of the young
carer\xd5 s needs for support, other needs and wishes.
A local authority, in carrying out a young carer\xd5 s needs assessment,
must have regard to
the extent to which the young carer is participating in or
wishes to participate in education, training or recreation,
and
the extent to which the young carer works or wishes to
work.
A local authority, in carrying out a young carer\xd5 s needs assessment,
must involve
the young carer,
the young carer\xd5 s parents, and
any person who the young carer or a parent of the young
carer requests the authority to involve.
A local authority that have carried out a young carer\xd5 s needs
assessment must give a written record of the assessment to
the young carer,
the young carer\xd5 s parents, and
any person to whom the young carer or a parent of the
young carer requests the authority to give a copy.
Where the person cared for is under 18, the written record must
state whether the local authority consider him or her to be a child in
need.
A local authority in England must take reasonable steps to identify
the extent to which there are young carers within their area who
have needs for support.
Young carers\xd5 needs assessments: supplementary
This section applies for the purposes of section 17ZA.
\xd2 Parent\xd3 , in relation to a young carer, includes
a parent of the young carer who does not have parental
responsibility for the young carer, and
a person who is not a parent of the young carer but who has
parental responsibility for the young carer.
A person is not a young carer if the person provides or intends to
provide care
under or by virtue of a contract, or
as voluntary work.
But in a case where the local authority consider that the relationship
between the person cared for and the person under 18 providing or
intending to provide care is such that it would be appropriate for
the person under 18 to be regarded as a young carer, that person is
to be regarded as such (and subsection (3) is therefore to be ignored
in that case).
The references in section 17ZA and this section to providing care
include a reference to providing practical or emotional support.
Where a local authority
are required to carry out a young carer\xd5 s needs assessment,
and
are required or have decided to carry out some other
assessment of the young carer or of the person cared for;
the local authority may, subject to subsection (7), combine the
assessments.
A young carer\xd5 s needs assessment may be combined with an
assessment of the person cared for only if the young carer and the
person cared for agree.
The Secretary of State may by regulations make further provision
about carrying out a young carer\xd5 s needs assessment; the
regulations may, in particular
specify matters to which a local authority is to have regard
in carrying out a young carer\xd5 s needs assessment;
specify matters which a local authority is to determine in
carrying out a young carer\xd5 s needs assessment;
make provision about the manner in which a young carer\xd5 s
needs assessment is to be carried out;
make provision about the form a young carer\xd5 s needs
assessment is to take.
The Secretary of State may by regulations amend the list in section
17ZA(6)(b) so as to
add an entry,
remove an entry, or
vary an entry.
Consideration of young carers\xd5 needs assessments
A local authority that carry out a young carer\xd5 s needs assessment
must consider the assessment and decide
whether the young carer has needs for support in relation to
the care which he or she provides or intends to provide;
if so, whether those needs could be satisfied (wholly or
partly) by services which the authority may provide under
section 17; and
if they could be so satisfied, whether or not to provide any
such services in relation to the young carer.\xd3
In section 104 of the Children Act 1989 (regulations and orders)
in subsections (2) and (3A) (regulations within subsection (3B) or
(3C) not subject to annulment but to be approved in draft) before
\xd2 (3B)\xd3 insert \xd2 (3AA),\xd3 , and
after subsection (3A) insert
Regulations fall within this subsection if they are
regulations made in the exercise of the power conferred by
section 17ZB(9).\xd3 \xd3

Consideration of parent carers\xd5 needs assessments
A local authority that carry out a parent carer\xd5 s needs assessment
must consider the assessment and decide
whether the parent carer has needs for support in relation to
the care which he or she provides or intends to provide;
whether the disabled child cared for has needs for support;
if paragraph (a) or (b) applies, whether those needs could be
satisfied (wholly or partly) by services which the authority
may provide under section 17; and
if they could be so satisfied, whether or not to provide any
such services in relation to the parent carer or the disabled
child cared for.\xd3

Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Arrangements for living with former foster parents after reaching adulthood
The Children Act 1989 is amended as follows.
After section 23C (continuing functions in respect of former relevant
children) insert
Arrangements for certain former relevant children to continue to
live with former foster parents
Each local authority in England have the duties provided for in
subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.2v tup gniyatS-1168322: SubSection: (3) It is the duty of the local authority (in discharging the duties in section 23C(3) and by other means) to monitor the staying put arrangement.

ParaLine.String: in relation to a staying put arrangement.
A \xd2 staying put arrangement\xd3 is an arrangement under which
a person who is a former relevant child by virtue of section
a person (a \xd2 former foster parent\xd3 ) who was the former
relevant child\xd5 s local authority foster parent immediately
before the former relevant child ceased to be looked after by
the local authority,
continue to live together after the former relevant child has ceased
to be looked after.
It is the duty of the local authority (in discharging the duties in
section 23C(3) and by other means)
to monitor the staying put arrangement, and
to provide advice, assistance and support to the former
relevant child and the former foster parent with a view to
maintaining the staying put arrangement.
Support provided to the former foster parent under subsection

the staying put arrangement is not consistent with the welfare of the
former relevant child.
The duties set out in subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.2v tup gniyatS-1168322: SubSection: (3) It is the duty of the local authority (in discharging the duties in section 23C(3) and by other means) to monitor the staying put arrangement.

child reaches the age of 21.\xd3
In Part 2 of Schedule 2 (local authority support for looked after children)
after paragraph 19B (preparation for ceasing to be looked after) insert
\xd2 Preparation for ceasing to be looked after: staying put arrangements
This paragraph applies in relation to an eligible child (within the
meaning of paragraph 19B) who has been placed by a local
authority in England with a local authority foster parent.
When carrying out the assessment of the child\xd5 s needs in
accordance with paragraph 19B(4), the local authority must
determine whether it would be appropriate to provide advice,
assistance and support under this Act in order to facilitate a
staying put arrangement, and with a view to maintaining such an
arrangement, after the local authority cease to look after him or
her.
The local authority must provide advice, assistance and support
under this Act in order to facilitate a staying put arrangement
if
the local authority determine under sub-paragraph

the eligible child and the local authority foster parent
wish to make a staying put arrangement.

given by section
23CZA
.\xd3 \xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Duty to support pupils with medical conditions
The appropriate authority for a school to which this section applies must
make arrangements for supporting pupils at the school with medical
conditions.
In meeting the duty in subsection
the appropriate authority must have
regard to guidance issued by the Secretary of State.
The duty in subsection
does not apply in relation to a pupil who is a
young child for the purposes of Part 3 of the Childcare Act 2006 (regulation
of provision of childcare in England).
This section applies to the following schools in England
a maintained school;
an Academy school;
an alternative provision Academy;
a pupil referral unit.
In this section
\xd2 the appropriate authority for a school\xd3 means
in the case of a maintained school, the governing body,
in the case of an Academy, the proprietor, and
in the case of a pupil referral unit, the management
committee;
\xd2 maintained school\xd3 means
a community, foundation or voluntary school, within the
meaning of the School Standards and Framework Act 1998,
or
a community or foundation special school, within the
meaning of that Act.
The Education Act 1996 and this section are to be read as if this section were
included in that Act.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Local authority functions relating to children etc: intervention
Section 497A of the Education Act 1996 (which confers power on the
Secretary of State to secure the proper performance of local authority
education functions, and is applied to social services functions relating to
children by section 50 of the Children Act 2004 and to functions relating to
childcare by section 15 of the Childcare Act 2006) is amended in accordance
with subsection
After subsection (4A) insert
So far as is appropriate in consequence of a direction given under
subsection (4A), a reference (however expressed) in an enactment,
instrument or other document to a local authority is to be read as a
reference to the person by whom the function is exercisable.
Subsection (4AC) applies if a direction given under subsection (4A)
expires or is revoked without being replaced.
So far as is appropriate in consequence of the expiry or revocation,
a reference (however expressed) in an instrument or other
document to the person by whom the function was exercisable is to
be read as a reference to the local authority to which the direction
was given.\xd3
In section 15 of the Local Government Act 1999 (Secretary of State\xd5 s power
to secure compliance with requirements of Part 1 of that Act) after
subsection (6) insert
So far as is appropriate in consequence of a direction given under
subsection (6)(a), a reference (however expressed) in an enactment,
instrument or other document to a best value authority is to be read
as a reference to the person by whom the function is exercisable.
Subsection (6C) applies if a direction given under subsection (6)(a)
expires or is revoked without being replaced.
So far as is appropriate in consequence of the expiry or revocation,
a reference (however expressed) in an instrument or other
document to the person by whom the function was exercisable is to
be read as a reference to the best value authority to which the
direction was given.\xd3 \xd3

Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Disqualification from carrying on, or being employed in, a children\xd5 s home
Section 65 of the Children Act 1989 (person disqualified from fostering a
child privately to be disqualified from carrying on etc children\xd5 s home) is
amended as follows.
Before subsection (1) insert
A person (\xd2 P\xd3 ) who is disqualified (under section 68) from fostering
a child privately must not carry on, or be otherwise concerned in the
management of, or have any financial interest in, a children\xd5 s home
in England unless
P has, within the period of 28 days beginning with the day
on which P became aware of P\xd5 s disqualification, disclosed
to the appropriate authority the fact that P is so disqualified,
and
P has obtained the appropriate authority\xd5 s written consent.
A person (\xd2 E\xd3 ) must not employ a person (\xd2 P\xd3 ) who is so
disqualified in a children\xd5 s home in England unless
E has, within the period of 28 days beginning with the day
on which E became aware of P\xd5 s disqualification, disclosed
to the appropriate authority the fact that P is so disqualified,
and
E has obtained the appropriate authority\xd5 s written consent.\xd3
In subsection (1), after \xd2 children\xd5 s home\xd3 insert \xd2 in Wales\xd3 .
In subsection (2), after \xd2 children\xd5 s home\xd3 insert \xd2 in Wales\xd3 .
In subsection (4), after \xd2 subsection\xd3 insert \xd2 (A1), (A2),\xd3 .
In subsection (5) after \xd2 subsection\xd3 insert \xd2 (A2) or\xd3 .\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Provision of free school lunches
The Education Act 1996 is amended as follows.
In section 512ZB (provision of free school lunches and milk at maintained
schools)
in subsection (2)(a) after \xd2 subsection (4)\xd3 insert \xd2 or (4A) (or both)\xd3 ,
after subsection (4) insert
A person is within this subsection if the person
is a registered pupil at a maintained school or pupil
referral unit in England, and
is in reception, year 1, year 2 or any other prescribed
year group at the school.
The Secretary of State may by order provide for the
following to be treated as persons within subsection (4A)
registered pupils, or any description of registered
pupils, at a maintained nursery school in England;
children, or any description of children, who receive
relevant funded early years education, or any
description of such education, in England.
In subsection (4A)
\xd2 maintained school\xd3 means
a community, foundation or voluntary
school, or
a community or foundation special school;
\xd2 reception\xd3 means a year group in which the majority
of children will, in the school year, attain the age of 5;
\xd2 year 1\xd3 means a year group in which the majority of
children will, in the school year, attain the age of 6;
\xd2 year 2\xd3 means a year group in which the majority of
children will, in the school year, attain the age of 7;
\xd2 year group\xd3 means a group of children at a school the
majority of whom will, in a particular school year,
attain the same age.\xd3 , and
in subsection (5), after \xd2 \xd2 prescribed\xd3 \xd3 insert \xd2 , \xd2 relevant funded
early years education\xd3 \xd3 .
After section 512A insert
Provision of school lunches: Academies
Academy arrangements in relation to an Academy school or an
alternative provision Academy must include provision imposing
obligations on the proprietor that are equivalent to the school
lunches obligations.
\xd2 The school lunches obligations\xd3 are the obligations imposed in
relation to maintained schools and pupil referral units in England
by
section 512(3) (provision of school lunches on request), and
section 512ZB(1) (provision of free school lunches to eligible
persons).
Academy arrangements in relation to an Academy (other than a 16
to 19 Academy) that are entered into before the date on which
section (
Provision of free school lunches
)(3) of the Children and
Families Act 2014 comes into force are to be treated as if they
included the provision required by subsection (1), to the extent that
they do not otherwise include such provision.\xd3 \xd3
